Prediction example

Fabio Morgante

2019-04-03

Source: vignettes/prediction.Rmd
prediction.Rmd

This vignette demonstrates mmbr in the context of prediction. We first simulate three phenotypes (\(y_1\), \(y_2\), \(y_3\)) and genotypes at \(P = 1000\) loci (\(X\)) for \(N = 500\) individuals. Then, the goal is to predict phenotypes from genotypes for \(N_{test} = 100\) individuals, training our model on the remaining \(N_{training} = 400\) individuals.

library(mmbr)
# Loading required package: mashr
# Loading required package: ashr
set.seed(1234)
options(stringsAsFactors = F)

The data-set

The first step involves simulating phenotypic and genotypic data.

N = 500
P = 1000
true_eff <- 2
X = matrix(sample(c(0, 1, 2), size=N*P, replace=T), nrow=N, ncol=P)
beta1 = beta2 = beta3 = rep(0, P)
beta1[1:true_eff] = runif(true_eff)
beta2[1:true_eff] = runif(true_eff)
beta3[1:true_eff] = runif(true_eff)
y1 = X %*% beta1 + rnorm(N)
y2 = X %*% beta2 + rnorm(N)
y3 = X %*% beta3 + rnorm(N)

The phenotypic data was simulated assuming the same 2 causal variables affect each of the traits with different effects.

which(beta1 != 0)
# [1] 1 2
which(beta2 != 0)
# [1] 1 2
which(beta3 != 0)
# [1] 1 2

head(beta1)
# [1] 0.3910978 0.1355306 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000
head(beta2)
# [1] 0.8208315 0.1047051 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000
head(beta3)
# [1] 0.1543145 0.7113933 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000

Prediction with mmbr

For starters, we assume there are at most 10 causal variables (i.e., set L = 10), select the first 100 individuals as the training set, and compute the prior canonical covariance matrices.

L <- 10
test_num <- 1:100
prior_var <- mmbr:::create_cov_canonical(3)
prior_covar <- mmbr:::MashInitializer$new(prior_var, 0.2)

Then, we fit the mmbr model to the training set.

y <- cbind(y1[-test_num], y2[-test_num], y3[-test_num])
m <- mmbr::susie(X[-test_num, ], y, L=L, V=prior_covar)

Finally, we use the parameter estimates from the training set to predict phenotypes in the test set. The accuracy of prediction is calculated as the correlation between true and predicted phenotypes.

pred <- predict.mmbr(m, X[test_num, ])

results <- matrix(c(cor(pred[, 1], y1[test_num, ]), cor(pred[, 2], y2[test_num, ]), cor(pred[, 3], y3[test_num, ])), nrow=3, ncol=1)
results
#           [,1]
# [1,] 0.2486029
# [2,] 0.6032142
# [3,] 0.5242412
